Elephant Trophy Hunting

A horrible ego trip or a way to promote conservation efforts?

Daniel Goldman
Apr 21

Every so often I come across a twitter thread attacking trophy hunting. My first thoughts in response to attacks of trophy hunters are the following questions. Do you eat meat? Do you eat factory farmed meat? Do you enjoy eating meat? Then in what way are you better than a trophy hunter? This discussion focuses on hunting elephants in Africa, but parts of this argument apply to hunting of other species as well.

Some argue that ecotourism can replace trophy hunting. And it is possible. However, the economics of the idea just don’t seem to hold. A single trophy hunt brings in about $80,000. Ecotourism would require a large number of people to bring in that amount of money. As more tourists come in, more infrastructure would have to be built. Hotels would go up. With those hotels would come other store fronts, which means more clear cutting of land for development.

One of the main risks to elephant and other endangered species in Africa is habitat loss. Tourism would promote habitat loss. Moreover, even if we stop trophy hunting, it won’t stop poaching. And if we ban trophy hunting, poaching would become much more profitable as these bans result in black markets which produce gangs and organized crime syndicates. We saw this kind of pattern of events during the prohibition of alcohol in the United States. The prohibition resulted in a black market which funded the rise of the mafia.

But who are these poachers? I have to wonder if people think that African poachers are a bunch of white old men going around and killing animals for profit. While a lot of the trophy hunters do largely fit this demographic, poachers are a diverse group of people. Many of them are simply natives who are trying to provide some level of income for their household or supplement their income. Even in the case of organized poaching, these organizations are made up of largely native individuals.

Poachers and Poverty: Assessing Objective and Subjective Measures of Poverty among Illegal Hunters…
Conservat Soc, Official publication of Ashoka Trust for Research in Ecology and the Environmentwww.conservationandsociety.org

Something else to consider about poachers and poaching is that while ivory does sell, a lot of the demand for elephants is actually from the meat. For some reason a lot of people are shocked to find out that elephant meat is consumed in Africa. I’m not sure why. Humans have been hunting various elephant species for hundreds of thousands of years. I don’t speak French, so I cannot review the primary source (Fargeot 2008), but according to a summary report by Daniel Stiles, upwards up 22 tonnes of smoked elephant meat — equivalent to almost 60 tonnes of fresh meat — were sold in a major bushmeat market in a major market in Bangui, between 2005 and 2008.

Trophy hunters generally donate the meat to local communities, thus reducing the demand for meat produced by poachers. Combined with the amount of money that’s injected into the local communities and businesses, conservation efforts help maintain and grow native populations, even in the cases of endangered species. And while some of the money is skimmed off the top by corrupt governments, more area is dedicated to trophy hunting than is dedicated to the entire national park system in Africa, so conservation efforts are working to protect habitat. Indeed, it has been suggested that banning trophy hunting could make biodiversity loss worse (Minin et al. 2016).

I’m going to end with a little tu quoque and a philosophical counter point. One of the attacks against hunters is that they get a thrill out of the hunt and so these people are bad people, evil, creepy, yada yada yada. Maybe it’s true. But then so is anyone who eats meat and enjoys it. A lot of the people who attack big game hunters are consumers of meat. They enjoy it. Taking a photograph of your excitement after a hunt is no worse than taking a photo of that nice juicy steak and posting it on Instagram.

Life is important. Sustainability is important. I do think that we consume too much meat and that we need to live more sustainably. But I don’t think that we need to stop eating meat, or that we must avoid hunting meat, and I certainly don’t think that hunting is worse than collecting your steak from the store after it was processed through a factory farm. The only type of meat that is off limits, and the only creatures that should be off limits from hunting, are people. Maybe elephants are people. But very few even try to make that argument, even though that’s the only argument that would justify prohibition on trophy hunting, given that the data suggests that trophy hunting improves, rather than hurts, populations.
